summary: virus-induced syncytium formation is a common cytopathic effect associated with replication of numerous enveloped viruses in the families Paramyxoviridae, Herpesviridae, and Retroviridae. syncytium formation is caused by viral membrane fusion proteins that evolved to mediate virus-cell membrane fusion during virus entry. protein-mediated cell-cell membrane fusion followed by syncytium formation is a multistage process. reovirus fusion-associated small transmembrane (FAST) proteins are nonstructural viral proteins that evolved specifically to induce cell-cell, rather than virus-cell, membrane fusion. at 95 to 198 residues in size, the FAST proteins are the smallest known viral fusogens. the rudimentary size of the FAST protein ectodomains is incompatible with a membrane fusion reaction based on energy released from dramatic ectodomain structural remodeling. the disproportionate size of their endodomains suggests that FAST proteins may be more reliant on interactions on the cytosolic side of the plasma membrane than enveloped-virus fusogens. intracellular AX1 interacts with p14 in a Ca2+-dependent manner. it promotes postfusion, pore expansion stage of syncytium formation. this is the first demonstration that intracellular AX1 is involved in pore expansion. polyclonal anti-protein disulfide isomerase (PDI; Abcam), polyclonal anti-green fluorescent protein (GFP; Clonetech), horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-conjugated anti-rabbit and anti-mouse secondary antibodies were from the suppliers indicated here. the average number of syncytial nuclei per microscopic field was quantified. HT1080 cells transfected with p14 were treated with a 1:50, 1:25, or 1:10 dilution of AX1 antibody at 2 h posttransfection, fixed and Gi a yeast two-hybrid approach, using p14 endodomain as bait, yielded AX1 as a genetic p14 interaction partner. p14-p14 interactions were verified in vitro by coimmunoprecipitation and in cellulo by FRET analysis. p14-p14 interactions were sensitive to physiological intracellular Ca2+ concentrations. annexin is a p14 fusion cofactor involved in postfusion pore expansion. results suggest p14 interacts directly with AX1 in a Ca2+-dependent manner. chelating intracellular Ca2+ inhibited both p14-AX1 interactions and syncytium formation. annexins are a diverse family of ca2+-dependent membrane-interacting proteins implicated in a remarkable range of cellular processes. the conserved, C-terminal core domain comprises four repeats arranged to form a curved disc shape. the nonconserved short N-terminal domain of annexins is thought to interact with the cytoplasm-facing concave surface of the core domain. AX2 and AX5 present in virions promote virus-cell attachment and infectivity of human papillomavirus (56), cytomegalovirus (57), enterovirus type 71 (58), hepatitis B virus (59), and HIV (60). intracellularly, AX2 promotes formation of hepatitis C virus replication complexes and assembly of infectious HIV virions. extracellular AX1 promotes prefusion or membrane merger stages of myoblast fusion. intracellular AX1 functions at postfusion, pore expansion stage of viral fusogen-induced syncytiogenesis. pore expansion is an ATP-dependent event that is impeded by cortical actin. measles virus- and p14-induced syncytium formation inhibited. intracellular Ca2+ is therefore an essential factor for measles virus- and p14-induced syncytium formation, promoting the pore expansion stage of syncytium formation. p14 activates endoplasmic reticulum store-operated Ca2+ channels. the FAST proteins are the smallest known membrane fusion proteins. they are the only viral fusogens that specifically evolved to induce cell-cell, rather than virus-cell, membrane fusion.
